topic: Examination of the Elbow: Congenital Radial Head Dislocation
text: Congenital dislocation of the radial head, most commonly anterior, presents with a fullness over the radial aspect, restricted supination and extension, and may be associated with cubitus valgus or varus. Examine the contralateral elbow and screen for associated conditions like Nail Patella syndrome or achondroplasia. Management is usually non-operative unless there is significant pain or reduced ROM.

topic: Examination of the Elbow: Cubitus Valgus/Varus and Nerve Status
text: Assessing cubitus valgus or varus involves evaluating ROM and palpating the medial epicondyle and ulna nerve for pain or subluxation. Crucially, examine the ulnar nerve's status in the hand, assessing sensation in the little finger and ulnar side of the dorsum, and motor function of intrinsic muscles and the flexor digitorum profundus to the ring finger. Tests like Tinel's at the cubital tunnel and the Wartenberg sign help localize nerve issues.

topic: Examination of the Elbow: General Assessment
text: General elbow examination involves inspecting for scars, asymmetry, carrying angle, swelling, and obvious loss of motion. Assess active and passive ROM in extension, flexion, supination, and pronation, comparing to the contralateral side. Palpate systematically for pain over the lateral epicondyle, RC joint, olecranon, medial epicondyle, and ulna nerve, assessing for subluxation or tenderness.

topic: Examination of the Elbow: Radio-Ulnar Synostosis
text: Radio-ulnar synostosis involves the failure of differentiation of the radius and ulna, typically resulting in a fixed pronation deformity. Examination may reveal scars from trauma, limb shortening, and restricted pronation/supination. Traumatic synostosis is associated with high-energy injuries, head injuries, and restricted post-operative ROM. Management is often non-operative due to poor surgical outcomes.

topic: Examination of the Elbow: Rheumatoid Arthritis
text: Examining an elbow with rheumatoid arthritis involves noting the typical rheumatoid features in the hand, wrist, and shoulder, along with any scars on the elbow. Assess elbow ROM, noting pain, crepitus, and warmth. Examine the ulnar nerve for neurological deficits and screen for spinal involvement. Functional assessment includes grip strength and the ability to perform daily activities.

topic: Examination of the Elbow: Stiff Elbow
text: Evaluating a stiff elbow involves assessing both active and passive range of motion to identify any pain within the arc of movement and quantify the degree of stiffness. Functional assessment includes the ability to bring the hand to the mouth and perineum. The presence of crepitus or pain with varus/valgus stress is also noted.

topic: Examination of the Elbow: Tennis or Golfer's Elbow
text: For suspected tennis or golfer's elbow, provocative tests include resisted wrist extension and third finger extension for tennis elbow, and resisted finger flexion for golfer's elbow. Assessment also involves palpating the epicondyles for tenderness and evaluating elbow ROM for any pain or restriction.

topic: Examination of the Shoulder: Instability
text: Assessing shoulder instability involves looking for asymmetry, wasting, and signs of hyperlaxity (Beighton's score). Palpate the axillary nerve for function. Special tests include the sulcus sign, anterior and posterior load shift tests (sitting), and the anterior apprehension test (lying). Testing the long head of biceps (LHB) if other tests are equivocal is also part of the assessment.

topic: Examination of the Shoulder: Rotator Cuff, Impingement, and ACJ Arthritis
text: Shoulder examination begins with inspection for asymmetry, scars, and muscle wasting in the deltoid, supraspinatus, and infraspinatus fossae. Palpate the clavicle, ACJ, acromion, LHB, and scapula. Assess active and passive ROM, noting pain, impingement arcs, and scapular winging. Special tests like Hawkins impingement, Jobes, and cross-arm adduction help identify rotator cuff pathology and ACJ involvement. Evaluating LHB and subscapularis strength is also important.

topic: Examination of the Brachial Plexus: History and Inspection
text: Brachial plexus examination begins with a history of birth trauma, prematurity, or associated conditions. Inspection includes observing limb posture, muscle wasting, fasciculations, scars (indicating previous exploration or nerve transfers), bony malunion, Horner's syndrome, and any walking aids or orthoses. Assessing the C-spine is also important due to potential associated injuries.

topic: Examination of the Brachial Plexus: Palpation and Movement
text: Palpation involves assessing bony landmarks for old fractures and evaluating sensation along dermatomes and peripheral nerve distributions. Motor testing is performed systematically by nerve root (C5-T1), trunk, cord, and branch levels to assess specific muscle groups like the rhomboids, serratus anterior, deltoid, biceps, and intrinsic hand muscles.

topic: Hand Examination: Carpal Tunnel Syndrome
text: Assessing for Carpal Tunnel Syndrome involves examining the neck and shoulders for associated issues, screening hands and wrists for scars and thenar wasting, and evaluating sensation in the radial three digits and thenar eminence. Motor assessment includes APB and FDS power. Special tests like Tinel's sign over the carpal tunnel and Durkin's compression test help confirm the diagnosis.

topic: Hand Examination: Nerve Lesions
text: Assessing nerve lesions involves evaluating sensation and motor function for radial, ulnar, median, musculocutaneous, and axillary nerves. Specific myotomes and dermatomes are tested to localize the lesion. Special tests like Tinel's, Phalen's, and Froment's sign help differentiate nerve entrapment or injury sites.

topic: Hand Examination: Rheumatoid Arthritis Findings
text: In rheumatoid arthritis, the hand examination reveals extensor surface changes like ulnar deviation, MCPJ subluxation, Z-thumb deformity, Boutonniere/Swan neck deformities, rheumatoid nodules, and joint inflammation. Flexor surface findings include trigger fingers and other deformities. Functional assessment includes grip, pinch, and chuck pinch strength.

topic: Hand Examination: Screen and Refined Assessment
text: The initial hand screen involves exposing the arms above the elbows, making a fist, opening the hands, and raising the arms to assess elbows and posterior arms. A refined examination involves inspecting and palpating for swelling, tenderness, mobility, and skin changes, and assessing distal neurological and vascular status. Special tests like Allen's test and specific tests for Dupuytren's contracture (Hueson's table test) are then performed.

topic: Hand Examination: Wrist Pain Assessment
text: Wrist examination involves inspecting for scars, deformities, and assessing ROM in all planes, including pronation, supination, and radial/ulnar deviation. Palpate systematically for tenderness around the wrist, and perform special tests like the Finklestein test (de Quervain's tenosynovitis), Watson test (scapholunate instability), and DRUJ ballotment (piano key sign) to identify specific pathologies.

topic: Clinical Examination of the Hip
text: Hip examination involves assessing gait, standing posture (pelvic tilt, leg lengths), palpation of bony landmarks, and ROM. Specific tests like the Thomas test for flexion contracture and provocative tests for impingement are performed. Examination also extends to the spine and knee to identify compensatory mechanisms or associated injuries.

topic: Examination of an Arthrodesed Hip
text: With an arthrodesed hip, examination reveals a fused joint with preserved spinal and compensatory lower limb mobility. Gait is asymmetric, characterized by pelvic tilt and altered stride. Palpation of the fused hip shows no motion, and a false positive Trendelenburg test may be present due to the fixed pelvic position. A thorough neurovascular check is mandatory.

topic: Examination of Patellofemoral Joint Rotational Abnormalities
text: Examination of the patellofemoral joint for rotational abnormalities includes assessing coronal alignment, Q angle, foot pronation, scars, quad bulk, swelling, and Beighton's score. Gait analysis should note foot progression angle and patella orientation. Sitting, assess extensor mechanism competence, crepitus, tracking, and patella alta. Lying down, evaluate for effusion, facet pain, MPFL tenderness, patella excursion, tilt, and ROM. Examination of the thigh-foot angle and femoral version (prone) is also crucial.

topic: General Topics: Clinical Examination of the Hip
text: Hip examination involves assessing gait, standing posture (pelvic tilt, leg lengths), palpation of bony landmarks, and ROM. Specific tests like the Thomas test for flexion contracture and provocative tests for impingement are performed. Examination also extends to the spine and knee to identify compensatory mechanisms or associated injuries, providing a comprehensive picture of the patient's musculoskeletal condition.

topic: General Topics: Examination of an Arthrodesed Hip
text: In an arthrodesed hip, examination reveals a fused joint with preserved spinal and compensatory lower limb mobility. Gait is asymmetric, characterized by pelvic tilt and altered stride. Palpation shows no hip motion, and a false positive Trendelenburg test may occur due to the fixed pelvis. A thorough neurovascular check is mandatory, and abductor function should be assessed to understand compensatory gait patterns.

topic: Clinical Examination of the Spine
text: Spinal examination involves observing posture, gait, and muscle wasting. Palpation assesses spinous processes and paraspinal muscles for tenderness or spasm. ROM is evaluated in all planes, with provocative tests like Spurling's (cervical) and SLR (lumbar) used to assess nerve root irritation. A comprehensive neurological exam (motor, sensory, reflexes) is mandatory to identify spinal cord or nerve root compression.

topic: General Topics: Clinical Examination of the Spine
text: Spinal examination involves observing posture, gait, and muscle wasting. Palpation assesses spinous processes and paraspinal muscles for tenderness or spasm. ROM is evaluated in all planes, with provocative tests like Spurling's (cervical) and SLR (lumbar) used to assess nerve root irritation. A comprehensive neurological exam (tone, motor power, reflexes, sensation) is mandatory to identify spinal cord or nerve root compression, guiding diagnosis and treatment planning.

topic: Useful Tables: Waddell's Non-Organic Signs
text: Waddell's signs are a set of non-organic findings suggestive of psychological overlay in low back pain. They include non-anatomical tenderness, simulation of symptoms, distraction-induced pain reduction, regional sensory or motor disturbances, and overreaction during examination.

topic: Computed tomography (CT)
text: CT provides detailed bony anatomy better than other studies and is useful for identifying tissue types based on Hounsfield units. It is particularly helpful in assessing spinal disc disease, differentiating disc herniation from scar, and demonstrating leg length discrepancy.

topic: Imaging and Special Studies: CT
text: CT provides detailed bony anatomy better than other studies and is useful for identifying tissue types based on Hounsfield units. It is particularly helpful in assessing spinal disc disease, differentiating disc herniation from scar, and demonstrating leg length discrepancy.

topic: Imaging and Special Studies: MRI
text: MRI is excellent for evaluating soft tissues and bone marrow, making it the study of choice for assessing ligamentous and meniscal injuries, and shoulder cuff injuries. It is also used to evaluate osteonecrosis, neoplasms, infection, and trauma. However, it is less effective for evaluating trabecular bone and cortical bone.

topic: MRI in musculoskeletal imaging
text: Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) is excellent for evaluating soft tissues and bone marrow, making it the study of choice for assessing ligamentous and meniscal injuries, and shoulder cuff injuries. It is also used to evaluate osteonecrosis, neoplasms, infection, and trauma.

topic: Imaging and Special Studies: Ultrasonography
text: Ultrasonography is increasingly used for evaluating soft tissues, including rotator cuff tears in the shoulder, diagnosis and follow-up of developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH), and assessment of articular cartilage and intraarticular fluid in the knee.

topic: Ultrasonography
text: Ultrasonography is increasingly used for evaluating soft tissues, including rotator cuff tears in the shoulder, diagnosis and follow-up of developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH), and assessment of articular cartilage and intraarticular fluid in the knee.

topic: Imaging and Special Studies: Nuclear medicine
text: Nuclear medicine studies, such as bone scans, gallium scans, and indium scans, are valuable for detecting inflammation, infection, and neoplasia by assessing blood flow and metabolic activity. They help identify subtle fractures, avascular necrosis, osteomyelitis, and infections associated with implants.

topic: Nuclear medicine studies
text: Nuclear medicine studies like bone scans (using Technetium Tc 99m phosphate complexes) and gallium scans are valuable for detecting inflammation, infection, and neoplasia by assessing blood flow and metabolic activity in specific tissues.

topic: Imaging and Special Studies: Radiation safety
text: Radiation safety should be considered in all fluoroscopic cases, with factors like imaging larger body parts, positioning the extremity closer to the x-source, and using large C-arms increasing exposure. Minimizing exposure time, using collimation, and employing protective shielding can reduce radiation dose.

topic: Radiation Doses from Medical Imaging
text: Different medical imaging procedures involve varying radiation doses. Angiography can deliver up to 57 mSv over 15-20 years. A CT neck is about 0.6 mSv, CT Abdomen/Pelvis 10 mSv, and CXR 0.1 mSv. Bone scans (99mTc) are about 3 mSv. DEXA scans and limb X-rays have negligible doses (<1 day background).

topic: Orthopaedic Classifications: Impending Pathologic Fracture (Mirel's Score)
text: Mirel's score predicts the likelihood of an impending pathologic fracture based on location (upper limb, lower limb, proximal femur), appearance (sclerotic, mixed, lytic), size (<1/3, <2/3, >2/3), and pain level (no pain, moderate pain, unable to WB). A score of 8 or more suggests an impending fracture requiring intervention.

topic: Plaster Casts: Plaster of Paris vs. Synthetic
text: Plaster of Paris casts are inexpensive and mouldable but heavy and not waterproof. Synthetic casts (fiberglass) are stronger, lighter, waterproof, and available in colors, but less mouldable and more expensive. Both are used for fracture immobilization, with the choice depending on specific clinical needs and cost considerations.

topic: Useful Tables: Positions for Joint Arthrodesis
text: Optimal positions for joint fusion vary to maximize function. For the hip, it's 30 flexion, 5 adduction, 10 ER. For the shoulder, 30 flexion, 30 abduction, 30 IR is critical for grip. Elbow arthrodesis aims for a functional arc of flexion.

topic: Useful Tables: Impending Pathologic Fracture (Mirel's Score)
text: Mirel's score predicts the risk of impending pathologic fracture based on location, appearance, size, and pain. A score of 8 or more suggests a high risk, indicating that prophylactic surgical fixation is crucial to prevent fracture and its associated complications, such as further tumor spread or neurovascular compromise.

topic: Plaster Casts: Plaster of Paris vs. Synthetic
text: Plaster of Paris casts are inexpensive and mouldable but heavy and not waterproof. Synthetic casts (fiberglass) are stronger, lighter, waterproof, and available in colors, but less mouldable. The choice depends on fracture stability, skin condition, patient factors, and cost considerations. Both require careful application to avoid complications like pressure sores or compartment syndrome.

topic: Clinical Examination of the Hip
text: Hip examination involves assessing gait, standing posture (pelvic tilt, leg lengths), palpation of bony landmarks, and ROM. Specific tests like the Thomas test for flexion contracture and provocative tests for impingement are performed. Examination also extends to the spine and knee to identify compensatory mechanisms or associated injuries, providing a comprehensive picture of the patient's condition.

topic: Examination of an Arthrodesed Hip
text: In an arthrodesed hip, examination reveals a fused joint with preserved spinal and compensatory lower limb mobility. Gait is asymmetric, characterized by pelvic tilt and altered stride. Palpation shows no hip motion, and a false positive Trendelenburg test may occur due to the fixed pelvis. A thorough neurovascular check is mandatory, and abductor function should be assessed.

topic: Clinical Examination of the Spine
text: Spinal examination involves observing posture, gait, and muscle wasting. Palpation assesses spinous processes and paraspinal muscles for tenderness or spasm. ROM is evaluated in all planes, with provocative tests like Spurling's (cervical) and SLR (lumbar) used to assess nerve root irritation. A comprehensive neurological exam (tone, motor power, reflexes, sensation) is mandatory to identify spinal cord or nerve root compression.

topic: Plaster Casts: Plaster of Paris vs. Synthetic
text: Plaster of Paris casts are inexpensive and mouldable but heavy and not waterproof. Synthetic casts (fiberglass) are stronger, lighter, waterproof, and available in colors, but less mouldable and more expensive. The choice depends on fracture stability, skin condition, patient factors, and cost considerations. Both require careful application to avoid complications like pressure sores or compartment syndrome.

topic: Clinical Examination of the Hip
text: Hip examination involves assessing gait, standing posture (pelvic tilt, leg lengths), palpation of bony landmarks, and ROM. Specific tests like the Thomas test for flexion contracture and provocative tests for impingement are performed. Examination also extends to the spine and knee to identify compensatory mechanisms or associated injuries, providing a comprehensive picture of the patient's musculoskeletal condition.

topic: Examination of an Arthrodesed Hip
text: In an arthrodesed hip, examination reveals a fused joint with preserved spinal and compensatory lower limb mobility. Gait is asymmetric, characterized by pelvic tilt and altered stride. Palpation shows no hip motion, and a false positive Trendelenburg test may occur due to the fixed pelvis. A thorough neurovascular check is mandatory, and abductor function should be assessed to understand compensatory gait patterns.

topic: Clinical Examination of the Spine
text: Spinal examination involves observing posture, gait, and muscle wasting. Palpation assesses spinous processes and paraspinal muscles for tenderness or spasm. ROM is evaluated in all planes, with provocative tests like Spurling's (cervical) and SLR (lumbar) used to assess nerve root irritation. A comprehensive neurological exam (tone, motor power, reflexes, sensation) is mandatory to identify spinal cord or nerve root compression, guiding diagnosis and treatment planning.

topic: Clinical Examination of the Hip
text: Hip examination involves assessing gait, standingdeflation.

topic: Plaster Casts: Plaster of Paris vs. Synthetic
text: Plaster of Paris casts are made of gypsum and are cheap, mouldable, and expand slightly with swelling, but are heavy and not waterproof. Synthetic casts (e.g., fiberglass) are stronger, lighter, waterproof, available in colors, and harden quickly, but are less mouldable and less expansile. The choice depends on factors like cost, required strength, and patient needs.

topic: Clinical Examination of the Hip
text: A comprehensive hip examination involves assessing the patient standing (pelvic obliquity, scars, muscle wasting, leg length discrepancy, gait, Trendelenburg test), lying down (pelvic squareness, leg lengths, assessing correctability of deformities), palpation (greater trochanter, groin, paraspinal muscles), and assessing range of motion (flexion, abduction, adduction, internal/external rotation) using tests like the Thomas test. Examining the spine, knee, and neurovascular status is also crucial.

topic: Examination of an Arthrodesed Hip
text: In a patient with an arthrodesed hip, examination reveals pelvic obliquity, compensatory scoliosis, hyper-lordosis, leg length discrepancy requiring a shoe raise, and a surgical scar. There is no active hip flexion, abduction, or rotation, and any attempted motion results in pelvic tilt. Gait is asymmetric, slow, and involves compensatory mechanisms like equinus and contralateral knee flexion. A false positive Trendelenburg test can occur due to the fixed pelvis.

topic: Clinical Examination of the Spine
text: Spinal examination involves inspection from the front and back to assess alignment, asymmetry, skin changes, and muscle wasting. Gait assessment is crucial, evaluating for Trendelenburg, ataxia, heel-toe walking, pigeon walking, and Romberg's sign. Palpation of spinous processes and paraspinal muscles for spasm, and assessment of joint ROM with provocative tests (Spurling's, Lhermitte's for cervical; SLR, bowstring, femoral stretch for lumbar) are essential. A thorough neurological examination assessing tone, motor power (MRC grade), myotomes, sensation, and reflexes is mandatory.

topic: Orthopaedic Classifications: Impending Pathologic Fracture (Mirel's Score)
text: Mirel's score predicts the risk of impending pathologic fracture based on location, appearance (sclerotic, mixed, lytic), size, and pain. A score of 8 or more indicates a high risk, suggesting prophylactic fixation is warranted to prevent fracture.

topic: Useful Tables: Waddell's Non-Organic Signs
text: Waddell's signs are indicators of non-organic pain in low back pain assessment. They include non-anatomical tenderness, simulation of movement, distraction-induced pain reduction, regional sensory/motor deficits, and overreaction. Their presence suggests a psychological component.

topic: Radiation Doses from Medical Imaging
text: Medical imaging involves varying radiation doses: CT scans deliver higher doses (neck ~0.6 mSv, abdomen/pelvis ~10 mSv) compared to X-rays (limb ~0.001 mSv, spine ~1.5 mSv). Bone scans (99mTc) are around 3 mSv, while PET scans are significantly higher (~14 mSv).

topic: Orthopaedic Classifications: Impending Pathologic Fracture (Mirel's Score)
text: Mirel's score predicts the risk of impending pathologic fracture based on location, appearance, size, and pain. A score of 8 or more suggests a high risk, warranting prophylactic fixation to prevent fracture and associated complications.

topic: Useful Tables: Positions for Joint Arthrodesis
text: Optimal positions for joint fusion are chosen to maximize function and patient comfort. For the shoulder, 30 flexion, 30 abduction, and 30 internal rotation are critical for grip and function. For the hip, 30 flexion, 5 adduction, and 10 ER are commonly used.

topic: Radiation Doses from Medical Imaging
text: Medical imaging exposes patients to ionizing radiation. CT scans deliver higher doses (neck ~0.6 mSv, abdomen/pelvis ~10 mSv) than X-rays (limb ~0.001 mSv, spine ~1.5 mSv). Bone scans (99mTc) are around 3 mSv, while PET scans are significantly higher (~14 mSv), necessitating careful consideration of radiation risk-benefit.

topic: Orthopaedic Classifications: Impending Pathologic Fracture (Mirel's Score)
text: Mirel's score predicts the risk of impending pathologic fracture based on location, appearance, size, and pain. A score of 8 or more suggests a high risk, indicating that prophylactic surgical fixation is crucial to prevent fracture, associated complications like tumor spread, and neurovascular compromise.

topic: Useful Tables: Positions for Joint Arthrodesis
text: Optimal positions for joint fusion maximize function and patient comfort. For the shoulder, 30 flexion, 30 abduction, and 30 IR are critical for grip. For the hip, 30 flexion, 5 adduction, and 10 ER are commonly used. For the knee, 0-10 flexion with slight valgus and ER aims for functional alignment.

topic: Radiation Doses from Medical Imaging
text: Medical imaging procedures involve varying radiation doses: CT scans deliver higher doses (neck ~0.6 mSv, abdomen/pelvis ~10 mSv) than X-rays (limb ~0.001 mSv, spine ~1.5 mSv). Bone scans (99mTc) are around 3 mSv, while PET scans are significantly higher (~14 mSv), necessitating careful consideration of radiation risk-benefit and judicious use.

topic: Orthopaedic Classifications: Impending Pathologic Fracture (Mirel's Score)
text: Mirel's score predicts the risk of impending pathologic fracture based on location, appearance, size, and pain. A score of 8 or more suggests a high risk, indicating that prophylactic surgical fixation is crucial to prevent fracture, associated complications like tumor spread, and neurovascular compromise, thereby improving patient safety and limb salvage.

topic: Orthopaedic Classifications: Impending Pathologic Fracture (Mirel's Score)
text: Mirel's score predicts the risk of impending pathologic fracture based on location, appearance, size, and pain. A score of 8 or more suggests a high risk, indicating that prophylactic surgical fixation is crucial to prevent fracture, associated complications like tumor spread, and neurovascular compromise, thereby improving patient safety and limb salvage rates.
